pullRequest.title: [DS-4522] Logical item filtering (with DOI implementation)
pullRequest.bodyText:
References

JIRA: DS-4522 JIRA ticket ticket
Fixes #7855
Documentation: Wiki draft documentation page

Description
This feature allows selective filtering of items for DOI minting, as well as ways for administrators to override/skip those filters, and brings with it a complete generic logical filtering system for DSpace items (similar in concept to the XOAI XML filter definitions) that can be used by any other service or component of DSpace.
A more thorough explanation is at the draft wiki page
Instructions for Reviewers
List of changes in this PR:

Addition of classes in org.dspace.content.logic package, representing Logical Statements used in filtering
Refactor of DOI Providers to make use of optional filters
New item-filters.xml spring configuration for defining item filters, with some examples already included
Unit tests for logical filters, and updated tests for DOI providers to test filtering of items in DOI events
Test command-line client for trying out filters without requiring them in production configuration

To test:

Have a read a of the doco and get a feeling for how the filter spring configuration works, the difference between filters, operators, conditions, etc.
Take a look at item-filters.xml and look for some filters to test, or define your own
Use the command-line client to test out the filter over some items you know will pass or fail:
dsrun org.dspace.content.logic.TestLogicRunner -f FILTERNAME -i HANDLE
Enable DOI providers / connectors the usual way, and include the filter in identifier-service.xml (there is a commented-out example)
Test things normal operation with the DOI consumer, CLI tool, and make sure the filters are applied (unless explictly skipped with the CLI tool)
Test out the curation task registerdoi, which by default should always bypass any filtering. It can be configured to obey filters instead, and to distribute across collections. (see config/modules/doi-curation.cfg)

Checklist
This checklist provides a reminder of what we are going to look for when reviewing your PR. You need not complete this checklist prior to creating your PR (draft PRs are always welcome). If you are unsure about an item in the checklist, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help!

 My PR is not small, at well over 1000 lines long including the new classes, and DOI provider refactors. I hope an exception can be made for this new feature.
 My PR passes Checkstyle validation based on the Code Style Guide.
 My PR includes Javadoc for all new (or modified) public methods and classes. It also includes Javadoc for large or complex private methods.
 My PR passes all tests and includes new/updated Unit or Integration Tests based on the Code Testing Guide.
 My PR includes no 3rd party dependencies
 My PR does not modify REST contract or Angular UI

+package org.dspace.content.logic;
+
+import org.dspace.content.Item;
+import org.dspace.core.Context;
+
+/**
+ * The interface for Filter currently doesn't add anything to LogicalStatement but inherits from it
+ * just to keep naming / reflection clean, and in case Filters should do anything additional in future.
+ * We need this as filters have to be specified in the spring configuration (item-filters.xml).
+ * Filters are the top level elements of the logic. Only logical statements that implement this interface
+ * are allowed to be the root element of a spring configuration (item-filters.xml) of this logic framework.
+ * A filter is just helping to differentiate between logical statement that can be used as root elements and
+ * logical statement that shouldn't be use as root element. A filter may contain only one substatement.
+ *
+ * @author Kim Shepherd
+ * @version $Revision$
+ * @see org.dspace.content.logic.DefaultFilter
+ */
+public interface Filter extends LogicalStatement {
+    /**
+     * Get the result of logical evaluation for an item
+     * @param context   DSpace context
+     * @param item      Item to evaluate
+     * @return boolean
+     * @throws LogicalStatementException
+     */
+    Boolean getResult(Context context, Item item) throws LogicalStatementException;

the name of the class should be updated to reflect the more general use case, maybe ActionAllowToGroupCondition
I would prefer that to default to false
better to use a primitive boolean

nodes.bodyText: this look to be a duplicate code that could lead to an ignored NPE in cleanup
better to log as it could help to trouble shooting issue in test cleanup

I disagree here as null is a very special value and we are hardcoding in the test the logic of our current implementation. Any statement about a null item could/should return false.
Can you switch the test to use a real item?
a test with an item without the checked metadata should be included

hi @kshepherd, what about making this exception unchecked rather than checked? In this way the callers of the methods that throw this exception would not be forced to handle it all the time, since it might not even be clear what it is due to and how to handle it. In a more general discourse, I would prefer to use unchecked exception instead of checked because they create problems with the use of lambdas and create a coupling between the different service layers of the system. What do you think about it?

Hi @kshepherd , sorry to jump into this discussion.
I understand the expected behaviour of this method as correctly explained in comments, and agree on what we really care about.
But with boolean as returned value, what happens if a client of this method, unaware of its behavior, calls it and makes his/her logic or whatever by handling a false return value that actually is not returned?
Thank you
